user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.2 is: Functions shall not call themselves, either directly or indirectly.

</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of metal_linux_dev_dma_unmap:
```c
static void metal_linux_dev_dma_unmap(struct metal_bus *bus,
				      struct metal_device *device,
				      uint32_t dir,
				      struct metal_sg *sg,
				      int nents)
{
	struct linux_device *ldev = to_linux_device(device);
	struct linux_bus *lbus = to_linux_bus(bus);

	ldev->ldrv->dev_dma_unmap(lbus, ldev, dir, sg,
				       nents);
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are close to the target function metal_linux_dev_dma_unmap:
struct linux_device {
	struct metal_device		device;
	char				dev_name[PATH_MAX];
	char				dev_path[PATH_MAX];
	char				cls_path[PATH_MAX];
	metal_phys_addr_t		region_phys[METAL_MAX_DEVICE_REGIONS];
	struct linux_driver		*ldrv;
	struct sysfs_device		*sdev;
	struct sysfs_attribute		*override;
	int				fd;
}
...
struct linux_bus {
	struct metal_bus	bus;
	const char		*bus_name;
	struct linux_driver	drivers[MAX_DRIVERS];
	struct sysfs_bus	*sbus;
}
</additional code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
struct linux_bus {
	struct metal_bus	bus;
	const char		*bus_name;
	struct linux_driver	drivers[MAX_DRIVERS];
	struct sysfs_bus		sbus;
}
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 17.2 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: No violation: the fragment is a struct definition (linux_bus) containing an array of linux_driver and other members. MISRA C Rule 17.2 concerns functions calling themselves (directly or indirectly). There are no function calls or function definitions in this fragment, so it cannot violate Rule 17.2. (Any potential indirect recursion via function pointers such as dev_dma_unmap would need to be examined in the functions that set/use those pointers, not in this struct declaration.)
